MISSING ADMISSIBILITY CONSTRAINT r >= 2j+3 FOR ROOT-OF-UNITY BLM MODEL:

The node discusses three open problems and the r -> infinity limit, all in the context of the BLM model at root of unity q = exp(2*pi*i/r) with fixed odd integer j. However, it NEVER states the essential constraint: the BLM spin parameter j must satisfy j <= (r-2)/2, equivalently r >= 2j+3 (for integer j, since r must be at least 2j+3 to ensure j is a strictly admissible spin).

Without this constraint:
- The quantum dimension [2j+1]_q = sin((2j+1)*pi/r)/sin(pi/r) vanishes when 2j+1 = r, making the BLM normalization factor sqrt(2JN) = sqrt(2j * [2j+1]_q * N) singular.
- The q-3j symbols C^j_q(m1,m2,m3) may be undefined or have poles.
- The supercharge Q_q is ill-defined.

This constraint is relevant to ALL three open problems:
- OP1: The admissible range for j restricts which BLM sectors can contribute to a TV-type sum.
- OP2: The Hamiltonian is only well-defined when j is admissible.
- OP3: The spin content comparison between BLM (odd j) and TV (l <= (r-2)/2) needs the admissibility constraint to even be stated correctly.

The r -> infinity limit paragraph should also note that the admissibility constraint r >= 2j+3 becomes trivially satisfied as r -> infinity for any fixed j. This was also raised as challenge ch-4246ac870af on the parent node 1.4 but has not been addressed in this child.
